name: Metaphor and novelty in science education visuals
author: Mol Mir, artist & planarian biologist
structural_details: 1) transcription of genetic material is like copying a book in a library: collection of metaphors buil up representation of library as the collection and source of information and the need to retreive this information to be and transcribed an make make copies
ontological_details: 1) ribosomes are 'workers' , 2) mitochondrial is a coffeeshop (energy source)
orientational_details: 1) cell cycle arranged in an infinity sign representing the endless repetition of making cells
imagistic_details: 1) a wobbly shape representing a cell (also described as a package),
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: use of structural and visual metaphors in text and graphics
entity_details: cell, organelles, material (chromosomes and ATP), stages of cell division, cells, and chrmosomes, time
process_details: cell division and DNA transcription over time
criteria_rationale: shows processes and has several actors that interact

name: Neurons Talking to Muscles
author: Peter Mindek, data visualisation
ontological_details: 1) choice of vibrant red/orange color to attract attention to acetylcholine which is the main actor (a molecule that 'talks'),
orientational_details: 1) phospholipid bilayer divides the composition in half dividing it into inside and outside of the membrane emphasizing that membrane divides two areas
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: neurons talking to muscles: the process of communication that represents a complex set of molecular interactions to facilitate movement (uses personification)
entity_details: acetyl, cholene, acetylcholine, acetylcholinesterase, acetylcholine receptor, phospholipid bilayer
process_details: communication between the neurons and the muscles through processing acetylcholine molecule
criteria_rationale: shows process of communication, uses several actors to show this process

name: Human Cell - A Molecular City
author: Peter Mindek, data visualisation
structural_details: 1) molecules in a cell functioning together: a dense cluster of units with different functions, processes that work together, and depend on each other to create proteins, just like a complex infrastructure in a dense city
orientational_details: 1) placement of steps in a circular clock-wise fashion that represents a cyclical and repeating process
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: structurel: molecular city as a structure working together with specific functions, ontological: function of cell parts e.g. mitochondria is the powerhouse and cytoskeleton functions as a railroad
entity_details: cell, DNA, nuclear pores, ribosomes, mRNA, proteins, microtubules, ATP synthase
process_details: describes the interaction between the 7 actors (in a cell- 8th actor) to create proteins
criteria_rationale: shows the process of protein production
depicted_process_time: takes nanoseconds for each step of to take place

name: An Improbable Life Cycle of a Parasite
author: Daisy Chung
ontological_details: 1) color yellow indicating that that is the stage when the parasite becomes invective compared to dormant/harmless blue color
orientational_details: 1) top-down approach to show passage of time
entity_details: bird, copoped, parasite, fish
process_details: the lifecycle of parasite that needs to be ingested by 3 hosts in specific order to survive
criteria_rationale: it shows a process that uses several metaphors to illustrate life cycle of a parasite
depicted_process_spatial: it takes place on organ level that the parasite inhibits in the various hosts

name: How Protein Subunits of COVID-19 Vaccines Work
author: Center for disease and Control Agency (OCD)
ontological_details: 1) uses vibrant colors to represent the harmful (red and yellow viruses) and good/ healthy (green: vaccine subunits),
orientational_details: 1) a paraller viusalization of the spike protein being modified on the left and the body's physical response on the right., 2) time goues from top to bottom to visualize the airborn properties of the virus (starting in the 'air' above the figure)
entity_details: virus, protein, person
process_details: process of proteins on virus that embed in the crown, symptoms of vaccine effects of COVID on person's body
criteria_rationale: shows stages of process that takes some time
depicted_process_time: time: few days that the subunits are working

name: Origin and Spread of COVID 19
author: ImpactScience
ontological_details: 1) uses yellow color to draw attention to the virus as if saying 'stay away, danger!', 2) highlights importance of two actors in the process, the bat and the human, who are rendered with higher detail
orientational_details: 1) The process of spreading between species is from left to right (past on the left and future/ present to the right), 2) places an ill human at the beginning to emphasize the effects of the virus on humans
entity_details: bat, virus, human, pangolian, time
process_details: origin and spread of coronavirus from animals onto humans
criteria_rationale: shows a process of passing the virus from species to species
depicted_process_time: time, this spread from species to species can take montsh to yeasr

name: Increasing Physical Activity Among Adults with Disabilities
author: SOURCE: 2008 Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans 2008; Exercise is Medicine, 2014, http://exerciseismedicine.org/
ontological_details: 1) Recovery through exercise is represented by a long, squiggly road, like a journey to recovery, with many steps and preparation.
orientational_details: 1) arrangement of stages of a healthy lifestyle into a road going from top to bottom and from side to side to emphasize that this is a long process, 2) doctor's assistance start-and finish are represented with the image of a doctor
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: steps to recommend aerobic activity with steps being visualized in graphics
entity_details: road, stages, people, time
process_details: the process of helping and individual with disability to start excercising and maintain their active lifestyle
criteria_rationale: shows process with examples of different metaphors that show higher level metaphors
depicted_process_time: time; it would take several weeks to months to establish an excercise rountine
depicted_process_spatial: this is aimed at a population of people with disability

name: Protect your family and community How Zika Spreads
author: CDC
orientational_details: 1) cyclical transmission of Zika virus shown by transmission stages arrangement in a circle, which takes up 2/3 of the infographic
entity_details: people and mosquito
process_details: transmission cycle of zika virus
criteria_rationale: shows process with basic metaphors
depicted_process_time: time: it takes several days for zika to develop and make its rounds after infecting
depicted_process_spatial: infection is talking about populations and species (people, mosquitos)

name: Fertilisation
author: GEnmics Education
ontological_details: 1) The color blue represents men and pink represents women: ingrained cultural metaphor where color represents an entire gender
orientational_details: 1) from left to right (from past to the future)

process_details: shows process of fertilization ion cellular level
criteria_rationale: process of fertilisation

name: Graphical Abstract: Nano Silver-Induced Toxicity and Associated Mechanisms
author: Jing Zhang,1,* Fang Wang,1,* Satya Siva Kishan Yalamarty,2 Nina Filipczak,2 Yi Jin,1 Xiang Li2
ontological_details: 1) hue of arrows chosen for its semantic value; dark arrows represent the dangerous nano-silver, green represent movement in environment, and red (life) represents human body
orientational_details: 1) top-down arrangement to illustrate how nanosilver in the air spreads to humans and all the way down to small scale to our cells while enclosing human in the center of the composition, 2) top-down, typical orientation metaphor where down is bad- decreasing health
entity_details: nanoparticles, places, individuals, organs, cells, organelles, molecules
process_details: passing of nanoparticles from enviroment through bodies all the way down to the cells
criteria_rationale: yes, shows a process overtime
depicted_process_time: absorbed into our cells in 10- 20 minutes
depicted_process_spatial: size: goes from molecular effect onto affecting organs

name: The Many Phases of Silver
author: Silver.com (Silver series)
ontological_details: 1) large green blobs represent bacteria as something undesirable because of their hue (green-brown shade), 2) shiny grey spheres are silver particles (shiny star also on the axe) that kill the bacteria (almost like a knight in shining armor- peronification)
entity_details: bacteria, silver
process_details: Simplified explanation of how silver kills bacteria by preventing it from forming chemical bonds on the surface it needs to survive
criteria_rationale: a simple explanation of complex process where silver and bacteria interact on molecular level
depicted_process_time: time- dropping bacteria into silver is pretty quick and molecular reaction take short time to occur

name: Visualizing the Evolution of Vision and the Eye
author: Mark Belan

name: Coronavirus Lifecycle, 2020
author: David Goodsell
ontological_details: 1) hue choice: vibrant colors (purple/ pink) are the dangerous viral molecules and green/blue are healthy cell molecules

entity_details: cell, viral molecules, cellular molecules
process_details: life cycel of COVID
criteria_rationale: Shows stages of process of COVID life-cycle
depicted_process_time: onset of symproms of covid when its spread enough is up to 1-2 days
process_time_cat: hours- days until COVID symptoms onset
license_type: CC-BY-4.0 and email from the author

name: Where is Coronavirus Rising and Falling?
author: information is beautirul
ontological_details: 1) cool hues represent falling (associated with health), and bright 'danger' colors represent the rising of covid cases (intense color), 2) the brighter the hue (yellow) in warm colors shows 'danger' in rising levels, levels that are on the rise and approaching more serious levels (orange), extreme cases (red), and very extreme cases with burgundy (Cameroon). In decreasing cases, darker navy blue represents some decrease in COVID cases, and light blue represents the most decrease in COVID cases.
orientational_details: 1) up is more, down is less (depending on which category, this is either good or bad), 2) to illustrate super extreme rising or falling cases, they continue outside of the graphics (Ecuador)
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: rising and falling of COVID cases- supports infographics (structural and ontological metaphors)
entity_details: countries, increase/ decrease, time
process_details: increase/ decrease of cases over a week
criteria_rationale: shows process of increasing/ decreasing cases in a given time
permission_use: yes from visual capitalist and information is beautiful

name: Climate change is affecting our local communities
author: King Country region official website
cultural_bg: Western (New Zealand but posters in 5 languages)
ontological_details: 1) use of red color that points to urgency about health impacts from changing climate
orientational_details: 1) texts about the environmental impact are on the outer layer, and going down to health and economic effects are placed inward on the right and bottom part of graphics- things from our surroundings are coming down on us from all sides (sea, mountains, air- we are surrounded by them)
imagistic_details: 1) the connection between individual effects is illustrated as a road
entity_details: climate change, environmental factors, economic factors, health factors
process_details: changes in economy, health, and environment as a result of changing climate
criteria_rationale: yes, shows process, made of several different types of metaphors
depicted_process_time: time: this can be years to decades
depicted_process_spatial: local: poster from website about Kings County, washington

name: What is Climate Change?
author: Ingenium energy
ontological_details: 1) hue choices- green and blue are good and healthy, while red/orange show importance and urgency, and grey shows the dying and bad man-induced influence, 2) rising temperatures are represented by an air balloon going up in the air, 3) in the middle of the infographics indicating that the future is already happening (future is abstract and it's being given physical representation) the unhealthy environment is moving into the healthy environment, e.g., an image of road contaminating river (bottom), fume from factory melting healthy glacier, grey cloud amongst blue clouds, 4) glacier metaphor: using melting of the glacier by man-made fumes as a set of actions that are destroying the entire ecosystem
orientational_details: 1) composition: healthy and damaged environment on each side of the infographics to show comparison, 2) putting the main metaphor at the top to show urgency (supports structural metaphor) where the eye is drawn to the first, 3) time from left to right (right is the future)
affective_vis: yes- cute bear will die once the ice is melted due to human activity + choice of colors for urgency
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: air temperatures are rising'
entity_details: change of temperature, greenhouse emissions, adaptation, climate change definition
process_details: Change in the environment (biodiversity, temperature, air...)
criteria_rationale: shows processes and several types of metaphors that stack together
depicted_process_time: time: year, poster states that these changes are visible from year to year
depicted_process_spatial: regional, this infographic is based on a report about a country (Canada)

name: CO2 Emissions vs. Vulnerability to Climate Change by Nation
author: Milken Institute School of Public Health, GW University
cultural_bg: Western (headquarters in USA, offices around the world)
ontological_details: 1) choice of hues: red is dangerous and draws attention (semantic meaning),
orientational_details: 1) the world is placed in the middle to draw attention and point out the overall state of CO2 emissions (which is bad) affecting it, surrounded by the emitting versus vulnerable visual statistics, 2) top countries are emitters (like being on top winning) and bottom are vulnerable (being beaten down), 3) division of the blue and red halves- juxtaposition- shows their very different qualities
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: vulnerable countries
entity_details: CO2 emitter, CO2 volnurable, country
process_details: the rpocess of emitting CO2 and being damaged by CO2 emissions
criteria_rationale: combination of different metaphors that describebe the making and effects of CO2 emissions
depicted_process_spatial: shows individual countries in a global context

name: State of the UK Climate in 2020
author: RMets
ontological_details: 1) red color for temperature as the main impact (draws attention and elicits urgency) that causes other occurrences (such as summer days) to rise behind it as a consequence, 2) escalator represents an increasing
orientational_details: 1) most dramatic increase is at the top, which leads to the other consequences, the snowy days are at the bottom because the year 2020 was one of the least snowy years (decrease in the snow- hopping off of escalator), in this case, up is bad, 2) from left to right (right is future)
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: temperature and sea levels increased, snow days decreased
entity_details: rainfall, temperature, day length, leaf season, sunny days, sea levels, general increase
process_details: increasing entities as a result of global warming
criteria_rationale: shows the process of changing climate: day lengths, temperature etc..... uses layers of metaphors
license_type: also received an email confirming we can use it

name: State of UK Climate 2022
author: MET offcie
ontological_details: 1) Newton's spheres (concrete objects) represent a process, imply impact with force and causality between the processes, 2) use of oranges and reds to represent temperatures and extreme weather to draw attention to those particular issues (urgency in Temperatures and Extremes- 2022)
orientational_details: 1) Newton's spheres with consequences go from left to the right (past-future), telling the viewer what starts the motion, 2) spheres with similar causes are clustered together (sea level, precipitation, and phenology), 3) the most extreme consequence (extreme heat) is flung the highest
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: knock-on effect' in text is shown visually through Newton's spheres
entity_details: Climate change, temperature, sea level rising, precipitation, phenology, extremes, earth
process_details: causes and following consequences of climate change on environment
criteria_rationale: shows the process of changing climate: day lengths, temperature etc..... uses layers of metaphors
license_type: also received an email confirming we can use it

name: Keeping It Cool
author: Woeld Wide Fund for Nature
ontological_details: 1) main cause of global warming that has to be reduced- the CO2 levels that need to be removed- is in red (urgency, draws attention), 2) use of green color to emphasize nature (also a positive color), image of a fan represents cooling
orientational_details: 1) things that need to be done are arranged like blades on a flower, while things that need to be removed are placed on a blade away from the fan, 2) Earth is at the center of the fan which tells us about the impact of the other things on Earth
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: keeping it cool' refers to outlined and visualized tactics in shape of a fan to slow down global warming
entity_details: nature-based solutions, cutting emissions for transport, plant-based diet, international collaboration, cutting emissions for making energy, Earth
process_details: improving climate by taking actions; either cutting emissions or removing them
criteria_rationale: using different metaphors to get the point across about cutting the emissions
depicted_process_time: time, plan for until 2045, therefore decades
depicted_process_spatial: cocnerned with specific country (UK) tehrefore regional

name: Climate Change is the Greatest Threat to Health
author: Health and Environment Alliance
ontological_details: 1) the use of orange color for communicable diseases that can spread- more danger, 2) the use of dark hues to represent an unhealthy environment and green hues to represent a healthy environment and bright, 3) the red bracket to show the urgency about who is at risk and what the risks are
orientational_details: 1) puts the 'harmful things' that need to be limited on the left and the 'healthy solutions' on the right (opposes them), 2) timeline from left to right, puts current (bad) situation on the left and bright future on the right
text_support_graphical_metaphor_details: climate change is a threat' and ',' tackling climate change'
entity_details: food, transport, buildings, factories
process_details: limiting fossil fuels and emissions from the 4 acrors
criteria_rationale: showing stepps to limit the effects of climate change
depicted_process_time: time is not specified, but some goals could take from few months (like cycling) to years and decades to take palce (green buildings)
